chapters.chapter_name: Lock-out and tagging procedures for electrical equipment
topics: Hazardous energy control devices and locks
CSA Z460 and CSA Z462 standards
chapters.content:
Chapter 1 - Lock-out and tagging procedures for electrical equipment

General lock-out and tagging procedures
As a gas technician/fitter, you may often be in areas where employees carry out maintenance procedures on powered machinery. At these times, detailed lock-out procedures are essential to prevent the unexpected operation and energizing of the machinery you are working on.

"Lock-out" must involve more than merely disconnecting the power source (workers have been killed by electrically de-energized machinery that has had its hydraulic systems still pressurized). You must thoroughly assess the machine and make all energy sources inoperative (including electrical, pneumatic, hydraulic, and gravitational). This is what is often called the "zero mechanical state".

As a technician/fitter, you should have your own lock and key (combination locks are not allowed) and only use these locks to lock out energy sources. Inform the machine operator of any maintenance plans and tag the lock to identify the individual who has locked out the machinery.

Note: The only person permitted to remove a lock is the person who placed the lock on the machinery.

These procedures apply both to stationary industrial equipment and mobile equipment (including passenger cars, truck equipment, and heavy construction equipment).

Lock-out requirements in CSA C22.1

Rule 2-304: Disconnection
1) No repairs or alterations shall be carried out on any live equipment except where complete disconnection of the equipment is not feasible.
2) Three-way or four-way switches shall not be considered as disconnecting means.
3) Adequate precautions, such as locks on circuit breakers or switches, warning notices, sentries, or other equally effective means, shall be taken to prevent electrical equipment from being electrically charged when work is being done.

Lock-out requirements: Refer to CSA Z460 and CSA Z462.

Hazardous energy control devices and locks
The control of hazardous energy associated with potentially harmful machines, equipment, or processes requires the safety team and individuals to follow strict guidelines. CSA Z460 and CSA Z462 are recognized standards for the protection of personnel from injury from the inadvertent release of hazardous energy.

"Release of hazardous energy" includes any motion, energization, start-up, or release of stored energy that, from the perspective of the person(s) at risk, is either unintended or deliberate. "Lock-out" is recognized to be the primary method to control hazardous energy.

Workers must consult the employer's policies and procedures before conducting any work on equipment or systems with hazardous energy. Training and supervision are a requirement. You must always gain authorization from your employer or supervisor before attempting any work.

Responsibility of workers
Each worker who works on machinery or equipment requiring lock-out procedures is responsible for:
• Locking the control devices; and
• Removing their own lock(s) on completion of work.

Checking locked-out machinery
The person who applies the first lock in a lock-out procedure must ensure that it is impossible for the locked-out machinery or equipment to operate.

Removal of locks
Only the following people can remove locks:
• The person(s) who installed them; or
• In an emergency, the senior shift supervisor on duty (who must first make every effort to contact the individual who installed the lock) and subsequently ensure safe operation of the machinery or equipment.

Ensure that during shift changes, workers coming on shift place their own locks on all control devices before the individuals going off shift remove their locks.

Key box system
The use of a key box system is acceptable when multiple lock-outs are involved:
a) Two qualified workers (one of whom may be a supervisor) must be responsible for locking out the multiple control devices, completing/signing/posting the checklist adjacent to the key box, and placing keys for the locks in the key box.
b) All other workers who must work on the machinery or equipment must also lock out the key box using personal locks before commencing maintenance or repair work.
c) On completion of work, all workers must remove their locks from the key box.
d) The two qualified workers who locked out the equipment must then remove their locks from the key box and from the multiple lock-out points.
e) A written key box lock-out procedure must remain posted at the key box location.

Exception for central control system
When a central control operator manages systems, they shall lock out the central control and record the locked out portion and the time. They shall re-energize the system only on the instructions of the person who requested the de-energization, after that person has determined that it is safe to do so.

Motor disconnects
When motor disconnect switches are installed for lock-out purposes, the relevant person must simultaneously disconnect both the motor and motor control circuits from their power sources. These switches must be readily accessible, and if installed in elevated positions, access must be by means of a permanent ladder or stairway to a platform.

Working on de-energized equipment
Before work commences on any part of an electrical power system that, for reasons of safety, must operate in a de-energized condition, the worker in charge shall ensure the completion of the de-energizing and grounding (of the part of the system they are working on) and the lock-out of the controls.

Assurance of de-energization
When the control devices are not under the direct control of the worker, they must receive assurance from the person in charge of the control devices that the work may safely proceed. The person giving the assurance must record such an assurance.

Protection against re-energizing
Before commencing work on a de-energized part of a system, the worker in charge must ensure the protection of all workers against re-energization.

Authority to re-energize
The re-energization of a system must not take place except on the instructions of the worker who requested the de-energizing, or of a supervisor who has first determined that it is safe to do so.

Requirements of applicable electrical safety codes and standards

Electrical codes and standards
It is necessary for a gas technician/fitter working on or around electrical equipment to understand the national, provincial, and municipal codes and standards relevant to electrical work. These codes and standards are the authority for rules governing the installation, maintenance, connection, and disconnection of electrical equipment.

They are also the source of:
• Legal requirements affecting the connection and disconnection of electrical equipment
• Requirements for notification of the inspecting authority
• Requirements for necessary permits
• Requirements for additions or renovations to existing equipment

Electrical inspections and permits
Most jurisdictions require permits for all electrical work. The locally recognized electrical code covers the general rules governing the administration of electrical permits (typically in Section 2, "General Rules").

It is the responsibility of the electrical contractor (or whomever is responsible for carrying out the work) to obtain a permit from the local electrical inspection department before commencing work on the installation, alteration, repair, or extension of any electrical equipment. A copy of the electrical permit must remain posted in a conspicuous place at the site of work, until the completion of the electrical inspection.

Canadian Electrical Code requirements
The CE Code contains Sections and specific Rules that deal with the installation and maintenance of electrical equipment as it relates to gas-fired equipment.

Section 12 — Wiring methods: Deals with wiring installation requirements.

Section 14 — Protection and control: Covers the protection and control of electrical circuits and apparatuses, including circuit breakers and fuses.

Section 26 — Installation of electrical equipment

Heating equipment:

Rule 26-800: Scope - Rules 26-802 to 26-808 apply to circuits supplying power for the operation and control of non-portable heating equipment that uses solid, liquid, or gaseous fuel.

Rule 26-802: Mechanical protection of cables - Cables for all branch circuits or tap conductors within 1.5 m from the floor shall be adequately protected from mechanical damage.

Rule 26-804: Fuel burner safety controls - Fuel burner safety controls shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of CSA C22.2 No. 3.

Rule 26-806: Heating equipment rated 117 kW and less
1) All electric power for the heating unit and associated equipment shall be obtained from a single branch circuit used for no other purpose.
2) Circulating pumps and similar equipment need not be considered as associated equipment if not essential for safe operation.
3) Subrule 1) does not apply to a water heater using a gaseous fuel.
4) The branch circuit shall be permitted to be tapped as necessary, but there shall be no overcurrent protection in the tap to any essential equipment, unless the control equipment shuts down the heating unit if associated equipment fails.
5) Suitable disconnecting means shall be provided.
6) Disconnecting means shall be permitted to be a branch circuit breaker at the distribution panelboard, provided the panelboard is located between the furnace and the point of entry to the area.
7) Where a separate switch is required, it shall not be located on the furnace nor reachable only by passing close to the furnace, and shall be marked to indicate the equipment it controls.

Rule 26-808: Heating equipment rated at more than 117 kW
1) All electric power shall be obtained from a single feeder or branch circuit not used for other purposes.
2) A suitable disconnecting means shall be provided.

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is the main danger of static electricity?
assignment_questions.explanation: Static electricity poses a fire hazard due to potential ignition of flammable materials

assignment_questions.question: Complete the following sentence with the correct option. _______ is a physiological reaction or injury caused by electric current passing through the human body.
assignment_questions.explanation: Electric shock is the physiological reaction to electric current through the body

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following factors does not affect the electrical resistance of the human body?
assignment_questions.explanation: Abrasions on the skin do not significantly affect electrical resistance

assignment_questions.question: Complete the following sentence with the correct option. An electrical current over _______ can kill a victim.
assignment_questions.explanation: Currents over 30 mA can be lethal to humans

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following should you not do when rescuing a victim of electrical shock?
options: Free the victim from electrical contact
assignment_questions.explanation: Never touch an energized victim as you will also become shocked

assignment_questions.question: What is the normal maximum voltage-to-ground allowable in the branch circuits of dwelling units?
assignment_questions.explanation: Dwelling units have a maximum allowable voltage-to-ground of 150V

assignment_questions.question: What is the minimum distance from a natural gas meter at which arc-producing electrical equipment can be installed?
assignment_questions.explanation: Arc-producing equipment must be at least 1 meter from gas meters

assignment_questions.question: Complete the following sentence with the correct option. The term _______ refers to a situation in which all energy sources are made inoperative (including electrical, pneumatic, hydraulic, and gravitational).
assignment_questions.explanation: Zero mechanical state means all energy sources are inoperative

assignment_questions.question: Indicate whether the given statement is true or false. Three or four-way switches are considered disconnecting means.
assignment_questions.explanation: Three or four-way switches shall NOT be considered as disconnecting means

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following people may remove a lock used to lock out equipment?
options: The person who installed the lock or (in an emergency), a supervisor
assignment_questions.explanation: Only the person who installed the lock or a supervisor in an emergency may remove locks

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following people has the authority to reenergize equipment that has been locked out?
options: The worker who requested the de-energizing (or a supervisor)
assignment_questions.explanation: Only the worker who requested de-energizing or a supervisor may authorize re-energization

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following must be obtained before electrical work can be performed on gas-fired equipment?
assignment_questions.explanation: A permit must be obtained before electrical work commences

assignment_questions.question: Which (electrical) code rules apply to circuits supplying power to heating equipment that uses solid, liquid, or gaseous fuels?
assignment_questions.explanation: Rules 26-802 to 26-808 cover heating equipment circuits

assignment_questions.question: A cord-connected product with a motor having a rated output of more than 249 W (1/3 hp) must be equipped with which of the following?
assignment_questions.explanation: Motors over 1/3 hp require manually operated motor-control switches

chapters.content:
Chapter 2 - Atomic theory and electron flow

[Content covers atomic structure, law of electrical charges, production methods, and basic electrical concepts]

Law of electrical charges: Like charges repel, unlike charges attract.

Production of electricity methods:
- Thermoelectricity (heat)
- Electromagnetism (magnetism)
- Electrochemistry (chemicals)
- Piezoelectricity (pressure)
- Photoelectricity (light)

Electric current: Flow of electrons in same direction produces electric current.

Conductors vs Insulators: Conductors (copper, silver, aluminum) have low resistance. Insulators (plastic, glass, porcelain) have high resistance.

Direct current (DC): Current flows in constant direction.
Alternating current (AC): Current regularly reverses direction.

Using electricity produces heat, magnetism, and chemical changes.

assignment_questions.question: Which three particles make up an atom?
Which of the following particles carries the basic unit of electrical charge?
Complete the following sentence with the correct option. _______ gives an atom a negative charge.
Complete the following sentence with the correct option. An object is considered electrically neutral _______.
options: When it has the same number of electrons and protons
When the negative ions are removed
When the neutrons have been removed

assignment_questions.question: What is produced when electrons are made to move in the same direction?
Complete the following sentence with the correct option. When a material does not conduct electricity well, it is called a/an _______.
Complete the following sentence with the correct option. The term _______ describes a current that flows in a constant direction.

chapters.content:
Chapter 3 - Basic electrical theory

Electromotive force (voltage): Measured in volts (V). The electrical pressure that causes electrons to move.

Current: Measured in amperes (A). The flow of electrons through a conductor.

Resistance: Measured in ohms (Ω). The opposition to current flow.

Ohm's law: I = E/R (Current = Voltage / Resistance)
Also: E = I × R, and R = E / I

Series circuits: Only one path for current flow. Same current through all components. Voltage drops add up to source voltage.

Parallel circuits: Multiple paths for current flow. Same voltage across all branches. Currents add up to total current.

Series-parallel circuits: Combination of both series and parallel connections.

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following units indicates the strength of electromotive force?

topics: Law of magnetic attraction and repulsion
chapters.content:
Chapter 4 - Magnetism and electromagnetism

Ferromagnetic materials: Iron, steel, nickel, cobalt can be magnetized.

Law of magnetic attraction and repulsion: Like poles repel, unlike poles attract.

Magnetic fields: Represented by flux lines from north to south pole.

Permeability: Ease with which material accepts magnetic lines of force.

Electromagnetism: Current flow through conductor creates magnetic field.

Right-hand rule: Thumb points in direction of conventional current, fingers wrap in direction of magnetic field.

Electromagnets: Coil around iron core creates strong magnet when current flows.

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is not a ferromagnetic metal?

chapters.content:
Chapter 5 - Alternating current

AC generation: Rotating conductor in magnetic field produces alternating voltage.

Sine wave: AC waveform alternates between positive and negative.

Frequency: 60 Hz in North America (60 cycles per second).

Phase: Relationship between voltage and current waveforms.

Impedance (Z): Total opposition to AC current flow (includes resistance and reactance).

Power factor: Cosine of phase angle between voltage and current.

Capacitors: Starting capacitors (75-600 μF) and running capacitors (oil-filled).

assignment_questions.question: Which electrical current flows in both directions?

chapters.chapter_name: AC power supplies and transformer theory
chapters.content:
Chapter 6 - AC power supplies and transformer theory

120V AC receptacles:
- White: Neutral conductor
- Black/red/blue: Hot/live conductor
- Green: Ground conductor only

Transformer operation: Uses electromagnetic induction to step voltage up or down.

Turns ratio: Secondary voltage = Primary voltage × (Ns/Np)

Step-up transformer: Secondary has more turns than primary, voltage increases.

Step-down transformer: Secondary has fewer turns than primary, voltage decreases.

Autotransformers: Single coil serves as both primary and secondary. No electrical isolation.

assignment_questions.question: Complete the following sentence with the correct option. The colour of the insulation on the live conductor in a 120-V ac circuit is normally _______.

chapters.content:
Chapter 7 - Electrical measuring instruments

Common instruments:
- Voltmeter: Measures voltage (connected in parallel)
- Ammeter: Measures current (connected in series)
- Ohmmeter: Measures resistance and continuity

Multimeter (VOM/DMM): Combines voltmeter, ohmmeter, and milliammeter functions.

Measuring voltage: Connect voltmeter in parallel with circuit under test. Voltmeter must have high internal resistance.

Measuring current: Break circuit and insert ammeter in series. Ammeter must have low internal resistance. Never connect ammeter across voltage source.

Measuring resistance: Short test leads together, adjust for zero ohms. Connect to circuit under test. Never measure resistance on live circuit.

Variable ranges: Start with highest range and work down for unknown values.

assignment_questions.question: Complete the following sentence with the correct option. A/An _______ is used for measuring resistance and continuity.

documents.content:
CSA Unit 5 : Basic Electricity
Chapter 1                        
Electrical Safety for Gas 
Technicians
Gas technicians and fitters often work with electrical equipment that can 
pose serious safety risks. This presentation covers essential knowledge 
about electrical hazards, applicable codes, and safety procedures that 
every gas technician should know to protect themselves and others.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Purpose and Objectives
Purpose
Gas technicians/fitters often work in a variety of situations 
with electrical equipment that can cause injury to 
themselves and others. Students must be thoroughly 
familiar with electrical hazards, applicable electrical codes, 
and safety procedures that relate to their work as gas 
technicians/fitters.
Learning Objectives
Identify electrical safety hazards
Recognize potential dangers when working with electrical equipment
Describe electrical code safety requirements
Understand the regulations that govern electrical work
Describe lock-out and tagging procedures
Learn proper protocols for securing electrical equipment
Describe requirements of applicable electrical safety codes
Apply relevant standards to your work as a gas technician
Key Terminology
Arcing
Lightning-like discharge of electricity 
across an insulating medium or air 
space
Electric shock
Physiological reaction or injury that 
results from electric current passing 
through the (human) body
Equipotential
Having the same potential
Static charge
Accumulated electric charge that is 
present on an object
Static electricity
Energy in the form of a stationary 
electric charge such as that stored in 
thunderclouds or produced by 
friction
Zero mechanical state
State when you make all energy 
sources, including electrical, 
pneumatic, hydraulic, or 
gravitational, inoperative
Milliampere (mA)
Unit of electric current equal to one thousandth of an ampere
Electrical Safety Hazards
Two common electrical hazards are static electricity and 
electric shock.
Static Electricity
Static electricity is energy in the form of a stationary electric 
charge such as that stored in thunderclouds or produced by 
friction. A static charge is the accumulated electric charge 
that is present on an object.
The main danger from static electricity is arcing. Arcing is a 
lightning-like discharge of electricity across an insulating 
medium or air space. The arc can ignite flammable gases or 
materials that it comes in contact with. A good example of 
this phenomenon is the ignition of the fuel mixture by a 
spark plug in an automobile engine.
Electric Shock
When working with electrical equipment, you must be 
constantly aware of the hazard of electric shock. You must 
know what factors increase the danger of shock, how to 
avoid shock, and what to do when dealing with a shock 
victim.
Factors affecting electric shock:
•
Amount and path of current
•
Type of voltage (AC or DC)
•
Value of voltage
•
Length of time the body is energized
•
Condition of the skin
•
Area of contact
Current Effects on Human Body
Range (mA)
Effect
1 or less
No sensation
1-8
Shock is felt but not painful. Victim can let go. Muscular control is kept.
8-15
Shock is painful. Victim can let go. Muscular control is kept.
15-20
Shock is painful. Victim cannot let go. Muscular control is lost. 
Breathing is difficult.
20-50
Shock is very painful. Victim cannot let go. There are severe muscular 
contractions.
50-200
Severe muscular contractions and nerve damage. Possible ventricular 
fibrillation of the heart, causing death.
Over 200
Severe burns and muscular contractions. Victim cannot breathe 
during shock.
Note: Currents in the lethal range do not always cause death if the victim is given immediate medical attention.
Voltage and Current Dangers
Voltage Risks
In practice, operating a flashlight is usually perfectly safe. 
This is because the flashlight cell has a very low voltage that 
cannot overcome the resistance of human skin and current 
flow is limited.
The danger of shock increases as voltage increases, but low 
voltages are not necessarily safe. Contact with 120 volts AC, 
the common household voltage, has led to more deaths than 
with any other voltage. Note that AC voltages above 750 
volts are high voltage.
DC Voltage Dangers
DC voltages can be very dangerous. Industrial voltages as 
small as 42 volts DC can be lethal.
Although 75 volts can be just as lethal as 1000 volts, victims 
of high-voltage shock usually respond better to 
resuscitation. Provided that they receive the artificial 
respiration immediately, their chance of survival is good. On 
the other hand, victims of low-voltage shock do not respond 
well to artificial respiration, because the low-voltage shock 
causes uncoordinated twitching of the walls of the heart, 
which interferes with sudden restoration of normal pulses.
Human Body Resistance Factors
Moisture and Salt
When skin is wet or salty, its resistance drops 
to several hundred from several thousand 
ohms. Therefore, weather can affect the 
hazard of shock. Wet, humid, or hot weather 
causes perspiration, thus reducing 
resistance. On the other hand, cold, dry 
weather may increase skin resistance. 
Vigorous exercise can also increase 
perspiration and reduce resistance.
Abrasions
Because the insulating layers of skin are 
absent, abrasions reduce body resistance to 
well below 100 ohms.
Applied Voltage and Duration
Skin resistance changes according to the 
applied voltage. Resistance is lower at high 
voltages. The longer the application of the 
voltage to the skin, the lower the resistance.
Contact Points
The body has different resistance at different 
contact points. Between the ears, body 
resistance is only 100 ohms. Measured from 
hand to foot, resistance is nearly 500 ohms.
Rescuing Shock Victims
Act Fast
The most important thing is 
to ACT FAST. The resistance 
of the victim decreases with 
time, and the victim can die 
in just a few seconds.
Protect Yourself
Never touch a victim who is 
still connected to the electric 
power. If you do, you will also 
experience shock.
Disconnect Power
First, try to disconnect the 
electricity. If you cannot 
quickly find the switch or 
plug, try to pull the victim 
and live conductor(s) apart. 
Use a dry wooden pole or 
some other dry insulating 
material (such as wood, 
glass, paper, cloth, etc.). Do 
not use your hands or a 
conducting material.
Begin Resuscitation
If the victim is unconscious 
and has stopped breathing, 
start artificial respiration at 
once. DO NOT STOP until a 
medical authority advises 
you to stop.
Five Steps to Rescue a Shock Victim
Protect yourself
Do not touch the energized victim
Free the victim
Disconnect from electrical contact
Apply CPR
Use artificial respiration as necessary
Call for help
Contact doctor, nurse, fire department, rescue unit, or police unit
Continue resuscitation
Until a medical authority advises you to stop
Grounding
Proper grounding of tools, equipment, and sources of static 
discharge is essential for reducing the risk of electrical hazards.
You shall effectively ground portable tools and equipment that 
require grounding and are not permanently connected to the 
wiring system through the use of approved three-wire cords and 
three-prong polarized plugs inserted in grounded polarized 
receptacles.
You must install ground straps where necessary to prevent static 
discharge.
Double-Insulated Tools
Many modern portable tools may not have a three-pronged 
plug but instead are double-insulated and have a two-
pronged plug. A tool that is double-insulated provides 
equivalent shock hazard protection as a tool with a three-
pronged grounded plug.
If you use a power tool with a two-pronged plug, ensure that 
the tool is double-insulated. To determine if the tool is 
double-insulated, the tool should have certification (e.g., by 
CSA) and marking with either the words "DOUBLE 
INSULATED" or the following symbol:
Figure 1-1 Double insulated symbol
Electrical Code Safety 
Requirements
Code References
Electrical safety codes contain sections and specific rules that deal with the 
installation and maintenance of electrical equipment as it relates to gas-fired 
equipment. Most provincial electrical codes are either based on or fully adopt the 
Canadian Electrical Code. However, some differences may exist, and you should 
always make reference the code accepted locally or provincially.
Canadian Electrical Code
The following provisions are part of the Canadian Electrical Code, Part I (C22.1-18).
Section 2 - General Rules
Rule 2-032 Damage and interference
1.
No person shall damage any electrical installation or 
component thereof.
2. No person shall interfere with any electrical installation or 
component thereof except that when, in the course of 
alterations or repairs to non-electrical equipment or 
structures, it may be necessary to disconnect or move 
components of an electrical installation, it shall be the 
responsibility of the person carrying out the alterations 
or repairs to ensure that the electrical installation is 
restored to a safe operating condition as soon as the 
progress of the alterations or repairs will permit.
Rule 2-100 Marking of equipment
1
Required Markings
Each piece of electrical 
equipment shall bear those of 
the following markings 
necessary to identify the 
equipment and ensure that it is 
suitable for the particular 
installation:
2
Manufacturer Information
The maker's name, trademark, or 
other recognized symbol of 
identification
3
Technical Specifications
Catalogue number or type, 
voltage, rated load amperes, 
watts, volt amperes, or 
horsepower
4
Operational Details
Whether for AC, DC, or both; number of phases; 
frequency in hertz; rated load speed in revolutions per 
minute
5
Safety Information
Designation of terminals; whether for continuous or 
intermittent duty; short-circuit current rating or 
withstand rating; evidence of approval
Service Box and Distribution Point Marking
Service Box Marking
At the tim

Rescuing Shock Victims
Act Fast
The most important thing is to ACT FAST. The resistance of the victim decreases with time, and the victim can die in just a few seconds.
Protect Yourself
Never touch a victim who is still connected to the electric power. If you do, you will also experience shock.
Disconnect Power
First, try to disconnect the electricity. If you cannot quickly find the switch or plug, try to pull the victim and live conductor(s) apart. Use a dry wooden pole or some other dry insulating material (such as wood, glass, paper, cloth, etc.). Do not use your hands or a conducting material.
Begin Resuscitation
If the victim is unconscious and has stopped breathing, start artificial respiration at once. DO NOT STOP until a medical authority advises you to stop.
Five Steps to Rescue a Shock Victim
Protect yourself
Do not touch the energized victim
Free the victim
Disconnect from electrical contact
Apply CPR
Use artificial respiration as necessary
Call for help
Contact doctor, nurse, fire department, rescue unit, or police unit
Continue resuscitation
Until a medical authority advises you to stop
Grounding
Proper grounding of tools, equipment, and sources of static discharge is essential for reducing the risk of electrical hazards.
You shall effectively ground portable tools and equipment that require grounding and are not permanently connected to the wiring system through the use of approved three-wire cords and three-prong polarized plugs inserted in grounded polarized receptacles.
You must install ground straps where necessary to prevent static discharge.
Double-Insulated Tools
Many modern portable tools may not have a three-pronged plug but instead are double-insulated and have a two-pronged plug. A tool that is double-insulated provides equivalent shock hazard protection as a tool with a three-pronged grounded plug.
If you use a power tool with a two-pronged plug, ensure that the tool is double-insulated. To determine if the tool is double-insulated, the tool should have certification (e.g., by CSA) and marking with either the words "DOUBLE INSULATED" or the following symbol:
Figure 1-1 Double insulated symbol
Electrical Code Safety Requirements
Code References
Electrical safety codes contain sections and specific rules that deal with the installation and maintenance of electrical equipment as it relates to gas-fired equipment. Most provincial electrical codes are either based on or fully adopt the Canadian Electrical Code. However, some differences may exist, and you should always make reference the code accepted locally or provincially.
Canadian Electrical Code
The following provisions are part of the Canadian Electrical Code, Part I (C22.1-18).
Section 2 - General Rules
Rule 2-032 Damage and interference
No person shall damage any electrical installation or component thereof.
No person shall interfere with any electrical installation or component thereof except that when, in the course of alterations or repairs to non-electrical equipment or structures, it may be necessary to disconnect or move components of an electrical installation, it shall be the responsibility of the person carrying out the alterations or repairs to ensure that the electrical installation is restored to a safe operating condition as soon as the progress of the alterations or repairs will permit.
Rule 2-100 Marking of equipment
1
Required Markings
Each piece of electrical equipment shall bear those of the following markings necessary to identify the equipment and ensure that it is suitable for the particular installation:
2
Manufacturer Information
The maker's name, trademark, or other recognized symbol of identification
3
Technical Specifications
Catalogue number or type, voltage, rated load amperes, watts, volt amperes, or horsepower
4
Operational Details
Whether for AC, DC, or both; number of phases; frequency in hertz; rated load speed in revolutions per minute
5
Safety Information
Designation of terminals; whether for continuous or intermittent duty; short-circuit current rating or withstand rating; evidence of approval
Service Box and Distribution Point Marking
Service Box Marking
At the time of installation, each service box shall be marked in a conspicuous, legible, and permanent manner, to indicate clearly the maximum rating of the overc

documents.content:
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5: INTRODUCTION TO ELECTRICITY - TEST
CHAPTER 1: ELECTRICAL SAFETY HAZARDS
What is the main danger from static electricity? a) Electric shock b) Arcing c) Fire d) Burns
Electric shock is defined as: a) Static charge buildup b) Physiological reaction from electric current passing through the body c) Lightning discharge d) Equipment failure
At what current level can electric shock become painful? a) Over 5 mA b) Over 10 mA c) Over 15 mA d) Over 20 mA
What current level can cause a victim to be unable to let go of an energized wire? a) Greater than 10 mA b) Greater than 15 mA c) Greater than 20 mA d) Greater than 50 mA
What current level is considered potentially lethal? a) Over 20 mA b) Over 30 mA c) Over 40 mA d) Over 50 mA
Which voltage is considered high voltage AC? a) Above 120 volts b) Above 240 volts c) Above 600 volts d) Above 750 volts
What is the most dangerous household voltage that has led to more deaths than any other? a) 24 volts AC b) 120 volts AC c) 240 volts AC d) 480 volts AC
What is the resistance range of human skin? a) 10 to 100 ohms b) 100 to 500,000 ohms c) 1,000 to 10,000 ohms d) 50,000 to 100,000 ohms
What reduces skin resistance and increases shock hazard? a) Cold, dry weather b) Moisture and salt c) Thick clothing d) Rubber gloves
In electrical shock rescue, what is the most important principle? a) Call for help first b) Act fast c) Check for pulse d) Apply first aid
What should you NEVER do when rescuing a shock victim? a) Disconnect the power b) Touch the energized victim c) Use CPR d) Call for medical help
What is zero mechanical state? a) When equipment is turned off b) When all energy sources are made inoperative c) When electrical power is disconnected d) When machinery is idle
What is the maximum voltage normally allowed in dwelling unit branch circuits? a) 120 volts to ground b) 150 volts to ground c) 240 volts to ground d) 300 volts to ground
Which electrical code rules apply to circuits supplying power to heating equipment? a) Rules 2-100 to 2-200 b) Rules 10-002 to 10-006 c) Rules 26-802 to 26-808 d) Rules 30-100 to 30-200
What must be obtained before electrical work can be performed? a) A permit b) Electrical drawings c) Insurance coverage d) Equipment manuals
CHAPTER 2: BASIC ELECTRICAL THEORY
What are atoms made of? a) Neutrons, protons, and electrons b) Neutrons, ions, and electrons c) Protons, electrons, and ohms d) Molecules, particles, and charges
Which particle carries the basic unit of electrical charge? a) Neutron b) Proton c) Electron d) Ion
How is an atom given a negative charge? a) By subtracting electrons b) By adding electrons c) By adding protons d) By subtracting protons
When is an object considered electrically neutral? a) When it has the same number of electrons and protons b) When the negative ions are removed c) When neutrons are present d) When it has no charge
What is produced when electrons move in the same direction? a) Ampere b) Ohm c) Electrical impedance d) Electrical current
Materials that conduct electricity well are called: a) Insulators b) Conductors c) Resistors d) Capacitors
What type of current flows in a constant direction? a) Alternating current b) Straight current c) Direct current d) Variable current
What causes static electricity? a) Moving electrons b) Friction c) Heat d) Magnetism
What is an ion? a) An atom with equal protons and electrons b) An atom with a net electric charge c) A neutral particle d) A magnetic particle
Which materials have high permeability for magnetic lines of force? a) Glass and rubber b) Air and plastic c) Iron and steel d) Copper and aluminum
CHAPTER 3: SIMPLE ELECTRICAL CIRCUITS
What is the unit of electromotive force? a) Amps b) Ohms c) Volts d) Watts
What is the unit to measure electric current? a) Amperes b) Ohms c) Volts d) Watts
What is the unit to measure electrical resistance? a) Amperes b) Ohms c) Volts d) Watts
What is the unit to measure electrical power? a) Amperage b) Ohms c) Watts or horsepower d) Volts
What is the purpose of an electrical switch? a) To change AC to DC current b) To change DC to AC current c) To open or close an electrical circuit as required d) To measure current flow
According to Ohm's law, current in a circuit is: a) Directly proportional to applied voltage b) Directly proportional to resistance c) Inversely proportional to voltage d) Independent of voltage
In the formula I = E/R, what does I represent? a) Impedance b) Current c) Inductance d) Insulation
What type of circuit allows only one path for current flow? a) Open circuit b) Parallel circuit c) Series circuit d) Short circuit
In a series circuit, what must the voltage drop equal? a) Amperage in the circuit b) Resistance in the circuit c) Voltage of the energy source d) Power consumed
What type of circuit allows current to flow through multiple paths? a) Open circuit b) Parallel circuit c) Series circuit d) Short circuit
In a parallel circuit, what voltage is applied across each branch? a) Only what is required for the load b) 75% of source voltage c) The entire source voltage d) Variable voltage
How is total resistance calculated in a series circuit? a) R₁ × R₂ × R₃ b) R₁ + R₂ + R₃ c) 1/(1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃) d) (R₁ + R₂)/R₃
What happens to total resistance when resistors are connected in parallel? a) It increases b) It decreases c) It stays the same d) It becomes infinite
Power in watts equals: a) Voltage times resistance b) Current times voltage c) Resistance times current d) Voltage divided by current
What is 1 kilowatt equal to? a) 100 watts b) 1,000 watts c) 10,000 watts d) 100,000 watts
CHAPTER 4: MAGNETISM AND ELECTROMAGNETISM
Which of the following is NOT a ferromagnetic metal? a) Iron b) Nickel c) Copper d) Cobalt
What is the law of magnetic attraction and repulsion? a) Like poles attract, unlike poles repel b) Like poles repel, unlike poles attract c) All poles attract each other d) All poles repel each other
What term describes the ease with which a material accepts magnetic lines of force? a) Magnetism b) Density c) Permeability d) Conductivity
How can the magnetism of an electromagnet be increased? a) By decreasing current flow b) By increasing surface area c) By increasing current flow d) By decreasing voltage
What creates an electromagnet? a) Permanent magnetic material b) Electric current flowing through a conductor c) Static electricity d) Friction
Where is the magnetic field strongest in a magnet? a) In the center b) At the poles c) Throughout equally d) At the edges
What do magnetic lines of force represent? a) Electric current b) Voltage levels c) Magnetic field strength and direction d) Resistance values
In the right-hand rule for straight conductors, if your thumb points in the direction of current flow, your fingers show: a) Voltage direction b) Resistance path c) Magnetic field direction d) Power flow
What happens when two conductors carrying current in the same direction are placed near each other? a) They repel each other b) They attract each other c) Nothing happens d) They create sparks
What is electromagnetic induction? a) Creating magnetism with electricity b) Generating voltage by moving a conductor through a magnetic field c) Storing electrical energy d) Converting AC to DC
ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS - ELECTRICAL SAFETY
What is arcing? a) Curved electrical pathways b) Lightning-like discharge across an insulating medium c) Circular current flow d) Magnetic field patterns
Milliampere (mA) is equal to: a) One thousandth of an ampere b) One hundredth of an ampere c) Ten amperes d) One thousand amperes
What type of tools provide equivalent shock protection to three-pronged grounded tools? a) Battery-powered tools b) Double-insulated tools c) Cordless tools d) Low-voltage tools
According to the Canadian Electrical Code, what is required for electrical equipment marking? a) Only voltage rating b) Only current rating c) Maker's name and various technical specifications d) Only power rating
What is the minimum clearance between arc-producing electrical equipment and combustible gas vents? a) According to CSA B149.1 requirements b) 1 meter minimum c) 2 meters minimum d) 3 meters minimum
ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS - ELECTRICAL THEORY
What is conventional current flow direction? a) From negative to positive b) From positive to negative c) Circular motion d) Random direction
In a flashlight battery, which component is the positive electrode? a) Zinc container b) Carbon rod c) Electrolyte d) Sealing compound
What is thermoelectricity? a) Electricity from heat applied to dissimilar metals b) Electricity from chemical reactions c) Electricity from magnetism d) Electricity from light
Piezoelectricity is produced by: a) Heat b) Light c) Pressure on crystals d) Chemical reactions
What is the speed of electrical current effect in a conductor? a) Speed of sound b) Speed of light c) Very slow d) Variable speed
ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS - CIRCUITS
What is electromotive force (emf)? a) Current flow b) Resistance value c) Potential difference of energy source d) Power consumption
What is voltage drop? a) Voltage increase across loads b) Potential difference across individual loads c) Total circuit voltage d) Source voltage variation
What is a rheostat used for? a) Measuring voltage b) Varying current by changing resistance c) Storing electrical energy d) Converting AC to DC
In a series-parallel circuit, how do you find equivalent resistance? a) Add all resistances b) Use product-over-sum method for parallel sections c) Multiply all resistances d) Take average of all resistances
What happens if one bulb burns out in a series circuit? a) Other bulbs get brighter b) Other bulbs get dimmer c) All bulbs go out d) Nothing changes
What is the main advantage of parallel circuits? a) Lower current consumption b) Each load receives full source voltage c) Simpler wiring d) Lower cost
How does current divide in a parallel circuit? a) Equally among all branches b) Inversely proportional to branch resistance c) Directly

documents.content:
Gas Trade Training Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
100 Question Multiple Choice Test
Instructions: Select the best answer for each question.
Questions 1-100
What simple rule is used to determine the direction of magnetic lines of force around a wire? a) The left hand rule b) The right hand rule c) Ohm's Law d) Faraday's Law
What is always produced when current flows through a conductor? a) Light is produced around the conductor b) Heat is produced around the conductor c) A magnetic field is produced around the conductor d) Sound is produced around the conductor
What is generated whenever a magnetic field moves across a conductor? a) Amperage b) Voltage c) Current d) Resistance
Which type of electrical current flows in both directions? a) Bi-directional b) Alternating c) Direct d) Static
Alternating current is more versatile than direct current. a) True b) False
In North America, what is the frequency of alternating current? a) 50 hertz b) 60 hertz c) 70 hertz d) 120 hertz
What does the abbreviation "ac" stand for? a) Automatic current b) Alternating current c) Active current d) Applied current
What does the abbreviation "dc" stand for? a) Directed current b) Divided current c) Direct current d) Dynamic current
A complete cycle of alternating current goes from zero to maximum positive, back to zero, to maximum negative, and back to zero. What is this pattern called? a) Frequency b) Amplitude c) Waveform d) Phase
What is the rms current formula? a) Irms = 0.707 Imax b) Irms = 1.414 Imax c) Irms = 0.5 Imax d) Irms = 2 Imax
What is the peak voltage for residential 120V rms voltage? a) 120 V b) 170 V c) 240 V d) 85 V
In a purely resistive circuit, voltage and current are: a) Out of phase by 90° b) In phase with each other c) Out of phase by 180° d) Out of phase by 45°
In a purely inductive circuit, current _____ voltage by 90°. a) Leads b) Lags c) Equals d) Doubles
In a purely capacitive circuit, current _____ voltage by 90°. a) Lags b) Leads c) Equals d) Halves
What is the symbol for resistance? a) X b) Z c) R d) L
What is the symbol for reactance? a) R b) X c) Z d) C
What is the symbol for impedance? a) R b) X c) Z d) I
What is the unit of measurement for resistance? a) Henry b) Farad c) Ohm d) Volt
What is the unit of measurement for inductance? a) Henry b) Farad c) Ohm d) Volt
What is the unit of measurement for capacitance? a) Henry b) Farad c) Ohm d) Volt
What is the formula for inductive reactance? a) XL = 2πfL b) XL = 2πfC c) XL = 1/(2πfC) d) XL = 1/(2πfL)
What is the formula for capacitive reactance? a) XC = 2πfL b) XC = 2πfC c) XC = 1/(2πfC) d) XC = 1/(2πfL)
What is true power measured in? a) Volt amperes (VA) b) Reactive volt amperes (var) c) Watts (W) d) Ohms (Ω)
What is reactive power measured in? a) Volt amperes (VA) b) Reactive volt amperes (var) c) Watts (W) d) Ohms (Ω)
What is apparent power measured in? a) Volt amperes (VA) b) Reactive volt amperes (var) c) Watts (W) d) Ohms (Ω)
The power factor is the cosine of which angle? a) Phase angle b) Current angle c) Voltage angle d) Resistance angle
What are the two common types of capacitors used in single-phase electric motors? a) Starting and running capacitors b) Fixed and variable capacitors c) Ceramic and electrolytic capacitors d) Primary and secondary capacitors
Starting capacitors have capacity ratings from: a) 25 to 300 microfarads b) 75 to 600 microfarads c) 100 to 500 microfarads d) 50 to 400 microfarads
For capacitors connected in parallel, the total capacitance is: a) The sum of individual capacitances b) The reciprocal of the sum of reciprocals c) The product divided by the sum d) The average of all capacitances
For capacitors connected in series, the total capacitance is calculated using: a) The sum of individual capacitances b) The reciprocal of the sum of reciprocals of individual capacitances c) The product of all capacitances d) The square root of the sum
Normally, what color is the insulation on the live conductor in a 120V ac circuit? a) White b) Green c) Black d) Red
A conductor having white insulation is normally connected to which colored terminal on a 120V ac receptacle? a) Black b) Green c) White or silvery d) Darker or Gold
What color is used only for ground conductors? a) White b) Black c) Green d) Red
To which winding of a transformer is the current supplied? a) The secondary winding b) The primary winding c) Both windings equally d) Neither winding
If the number of turns on a secondary winding is greater than the primary winding, the secondary voltage is: a) Lesser than primary voltage b) Greater than primary voltage c) Equal to primary voltage d) Zero
How is the secondary voltage of a transformer calculated? a) By dividing primary voltage by the turns ratio b) By multiplying primary voltage by the turns ratio c) By adding primary voltage to the turns ratio d) By subtracting the turns ratio from primary voltage
What type of transformer has a secondary winding with fewer turns than the primary winding? a) Step-up transformer b) Step-down transformer c) Isolation transformer d) Auto-transformer
"Self-regulating" means that as the current flow to the secondary winding changes: a) The primary current flow remains constant b) The primary current flow also changes c) The voltage changes but current stays the same d) The transformer shuts down
What type of transformer consists of a single coil that serves as both primary and secondary windings? a) AC transformer b) DC transformer c) Autotransformer d) Isolation transformer
What is back EMF? a) Voltage that opposes applied voltage b) Voltage that adds to applied voltage c) Current that opposes applied current d) Current that adds to applied current
What type of electrical meter is used for measuring resistance and continuity? a) Ammeter b) Voltmeter c) Ohmmeter d) Wattmeter
What does DMM stand for? a) Direct measuring meter b) Digital multimeter c) Dual measurement meter d) Dynamic multimeter
What does VOM stand for? a) Volt-ohm-meter b) Volt-ohm-milliammeter c) Variable-ohm-meter d) Voltage-output-meter
To measure voltage, a voltmeter must be connected: a) In series with the circuit b) In parallel with the circuit c) Between ground and neutral d) Across the power supply only
To measure current, an ammeter must be connected: a) In parallel with the circuit b) In series with the circuit c) Across the voltage source d) To ground only
A voltmeter should have: a) Very low internal resistance b) Very high internal resistance c) Medium internal resistance d) Variable internal resistance
An ammeter should have: a) Very high internal resistance b) Medium internal resistance c) Very low internal resistance d) Variable internal resistance
Before using an ohmmeter, you must perform: a) Voltage calibration b) Current calibration c) Zero ohms adjustment d) Maximum resistance check
An ohmmeter should never be connected: a) To a dead circuit b) Across a live load or supply voltage c) To measure continuity d) Between test leads
On an analogue ohmmeter scale, you read: a) From left to right b) From right to left c) From center outward d) From top to bottom
When selecting ranges on measuring instruments, always start with: a) The lowest range b) The medium range c) The highest range d) Any random range
Digital instruments are necessarily more accurate than analogue instruments. a) True b) False
What is the most common source of AC power? a) Battery b) Solar cell c) AC generator or alternator d) Fuel cell
The movement of a conductor in a magnetic field induces: a) Resistance in the conductor b) A current in the conductor c) Heat in the conductor d) Light from the conductor
The amount of voltage generated in a generator depends on all EXCEPT: a) Strength of the magnetic field b) Speed of conductor movement c) Angle at which conductor cuts flux lines d) Color of the conductor wire
A single-phase generator produces: a) Three alternating voltage waveforms b) One alternating voltage waveform c) Direct current only d) Both AC and DC simultaneously
A three-phase generator produces waveforms displaced by: a) 90° from each other b) 180° from each other c) 120° from each other d) 60° from each other
The correct name for the AC waveform shape is: a) Square wave b) Triangle wave c) Sinusoidal or sine wave d) Sawtooth wave
In Canada, one complete AC cycle takes: a) 1/50th of a second b) 1/60th of a second c) 1/120th of a second d) 1/30th of a second
Phase can be described as: a) The difference in electrical degrees between two waveforms b) The maximum voltage of a waveform c) The frequency of alternation d) The total energy in the system
In an R-L circuit, the current will lag voltage by: a) Exactly 90° b) Exactly 0° c) Some angle between 0° and 90° d) Exactly 180°
In an R-C circuit, the current will lead voltage by: a) Exactly 90° b) Exactly 0° c) Some angle between 0° and 90° d) Exactly 180°
The impedance formula for an R-L circuit is: a) Z = R + XL b) Z = √(R² + XL²) c) Z = R × XL d) Z = R / XL
The impedance formula for an R-C circuit is: a) Z = R + XC b) Z = √(R² + XC²) c) Z = R × XC d) Z = R / XC
True power formula is: a) P = V × I b) P = V × I × power factor c) P = V² / R d) P = I² × R
Apparent power formula is: a) P = V × I × power factor b) S = V × I c) Q = V × I × sin θ d) P = I² × R
What prevents electron flow between capacitor plates but allows charge storage? a) Conductor material b) Dielectric material c) Magnetic material d) Resistive material
The DC resistance of a capacitor is: a) Zero b) Very low c) Medium d) Infinite
Starting capacitors are used for: a) Continuous motor operation b) Short periods during motor startup c) Voltage regulation d) Power factor correction
Running capacitors: a) Are used only during startup b) Stay in the motor circuit for the entire operation cycle c) Have larger capacity than starting capacitors d) Do not require heat dissipation
An electrical distribution system allows: a) Generation of electricity only b) Delivery of electricity only c) Generation and delivery

100 Question Multiple Choice Test 
Instructions: Select the best answer for each question. 
 
Questions 1-100 
1. What simple rule is used to determine the direction of magnetic lines of force around a 
wire? a) The left hand rule b) The right hand rule c) Ohm's Law d) Faraday's Law

produced around the conductor d) Sound is produced around the conductor

Doubles

Halves

1. Electrical safety hazards, safe working 
techniques, procedures, and applicable codes 
Overview 
Purpose 
Gas technicians/fitters often work in a variety of situations with electrical equipment that can 
cause injury to themselves and others. Students must be thoroughly familiar with electrical 
hazards, applicable electrical codes, and safety procedures that relate to their work as gas 
technicians/fitters. 
Objectives 
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to: 
• identify electrical safety hazards; 
• describe electrical code safety requirements; 
• describe lock-out and tagging procedures for electrical equipment; and 
• describe requirements of applicable electrical safety codes and standards.

Term 
Abbreviation 
Definition 
(symbol) 
Zero mechanical state 
State when you make all energy sources, 
including electrical, pneumatic, hydraulic, or 
gravitational, inoperative 
Milliampere 
mA 
Unit of electric current equal to one thousandth 
of an ampere 
Electrical safety hazards 
Two common electrical hazards are static electricity and electric shock. 
Static electricity 
Static electricity is energy in the form of a stationary electric charge such as that stored in 
thunderclouds or produced by friction. A static charge is the accumulated electric charge that is 
present on an object. 
The main danger from static electricity is arcing. Arcing is a lightning-like discharge of electricity 
across an insulating medium or air space. The arc can ignite flammable gases or materials that it 
comes in contact with. A good example of this phenomenon is the ignition of the fuel mixture by a 
spark plug in an automobile engine. 
Electric shock 
When working with electrical equipment, you must be constantly aware of the hazard of electric 
shock. You must know what factors increase the danger of shock, how to avoid shock, and what 
to do when dealing with a shock victim. 
Factors affecting electric shock 
When a person receives a shock, the electric current passes through the person, (usually to the 
earth or ground). The severity of the shock depends upon how much current passes through the 
body. The factors that affect the severity of a shock are: 
• amount and path of current; 
• type of voltage (ac or de); 
• value of voltage; 
• length of time the body is energized; 
• condition of the skin; and 
• area of contact. 
Current 
Any current over 10 mA can produce painful shock. Depending on the voltage and other 
conditions, a current greater than 15 mA passing through the body can paralyze the victim and 
make it impossible to let go of the energized wire. This is a very small current. An ordinary 
flashlight uses more than 30 times this current. Any current over 50 mA can kill the victim. 
March 2022 
9
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
Introduction to electricity 
Table 1-1 lists the physiological effects of various currents. 
Table 1-1 
Physiological effects of various currents 
Range 
mA 
Effect 
Non-lethal 
1 or less 
No sensation 
1-8 
Shock is felt but not painful. Victim can let go. Muscular 
control is kept. 
8-15 
Shock is painful. Victim can let go. Muscular control is kept. 
15-20 
Shock is painful. Victim cannot let go. Muscular control is 
lost. Breathing is difficult. 
20-50 
Shock is very painful. Victim cannot let go. There are severe 
muscular contractions. 
Lethal 
50-200 
Severe muscular contractions and nerve damage. 
Possible ventricular fibrillation of the heart, causing death. 
Over200 
Severe burns and muscular contractions. 
Victim cannot breathe during shock. 
Note: Currents in the lethal range do not always cause death if the victim is given immediate medical 
attention. 
In practice, operating a flashlight is usually perfectly safe. This is because the flashlight cell has a 
very low voltage that cannot overcome the resistance of human skin and current flow is limited. 
The danger of shock increases as voltage increases, but low voltages are not necessarily safe. 
Contact with 120 volts ac, the common household voltage, has led to more deaths than with any 
other voltage. Note that AC voltages above 750 volts are high voltage. 
DC voltages can be very dangerous. Industrial voltages as small as 42 volts de can be lethal. 
Chapter 5. Theory of direct and alternating current discusses the differences between ac and de. 
Although 75 volts can be just as lethal as 1000 volts, victims of high-voltage shock usually 
respond better to resuscitation. Provided that they receive the artificial respiration immediately, 
their chance of survival is good. On the other hand, victims of low-voltage shock do not respond 
well to artificial respiration, because the low-voltage shock causes uncoordinated twitching of the 
walls of the heart, which interferes with sudden restoration of normal pulses. 
n1 
The electrical resistance of the human body varies because of moisture, salt, and abrasions on 
the skin. Resistance of the skin varies from 100 ohms to over 500 000 ohms. The applied 
voltage, the duration of applied voltage, and the points of contact also affect skin resistance. 
10 
March 2022
Introduction to electricity 
Moisture and salt 
When skin is wet or salty, its resistance drops to several hundred from several thousand ohms. 
Therefore, weather can affect the hazard of shock. Wet, humid, or hot weather causes 
perspiration, thus reducing resistance. On the other hand, cold, dry weather may increase skin 
resistance . Vigorous exercise can also increase perspiration and reduce resistance. 
Abrasions 
Because the insulating layers of skin are absent, abrasions reduce body resistance to well below 
100 ohms. 
Applied voltage and its duration 
Skin resistance changes according to the applied voltage. Resistance is lower at high voltages. 
The longer the application of the voltage to the skin, the lower the resistance. 
Contact points 
The body has different resistance at different contact points. Between the ears, body resistance 
is only 100 ohms. Measured from hand to foot, resistance is nearly 500 ohms. 
Rescuing shock victims 
You must always take general precautions in the case of electrical shock. 
The most important thing is to ACT FAST. The resistance of the victim decreases with time, and 
the victim can die in just a few seconds. 
Never touch a victim who is still connected to the electric power. If you do, you will also 
experience shock. 
First, try to disconnect the electricity. If you cannot quickly find the switch or plug, try to pull the 
victim and live conductor(s) apart. Use a dry wooden pole or some other dry insulating material 
(such as wood, glass, paper, cloth, etc.). Do not use your hands or a conducting material. 
If the victim is unconscious and has stopped breathing, start artificial respiration at once. DO 
NOT STOP until a medical authority advises you to stop. 
Sumtnary 
In the absence of other instructions, follow these five simple steps to rescue a shock victim: 
1) 
Protect yourself-do not touch the energized victim. 
2) 
Free the victim from electrical contact. 
3) 
Apply cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) or artificial respiration, as necessary. 
4) 
Have someone call a doctor, nurse, fire department, rescue Unit, or police Unit. 
5) 
Continue resuscitation attempts until a medical authority advises you to stop. 
Grounding 
Proper grounding of tools, equipment, and sources of static discharge is essential for reducing 
the risk of electrical hazards. 
March 2022 
11

Atoms, electrons, and electricity 
Atoms and molecules 
Everything that has mass or occupies space is what you call matter. The smallest particle of 
matter that can take part in a chemical reaction is an atom. Atoms are the submicroscopic 
building blocks of matter. They combine to form larger particles called molecules. Atoms and 
molecules are much too small to be seen or weighed directly. 
Atoms and molecules form various elements and compounds. An element is a substance made 
up of only one kind of atom. A compound contains more than one type of atom, chemically 
combined. Water is an example of a compound . Each water molecule is made up of one oxygen 
atom and two hydrogen atoms. To understand electricity, you must know something about the 
structure of atoms. 
Atomic structure 
Atoms are made up of smaller particles, called subatomic particles: 
• neutrons; 
• protons; and 
• electrons. 
Although scientists have found further subdivisions of these particles, it is only necessary for our 
understanding of electricity to focus on protons and electrons. 
Figure 2-1 
A carbon atom 
The centre of the atom is the nucleus (plural nuclei), which houses protons and neutrons. 
Electrons revolve around the nucleus in orbits. See Figure 2-1, a diagram of a carbon atom. 
March 2022 
27
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
Introduction to electricity 
The number of electrons, protons, and neutrons in the atoms of an element determines how that 
element behaves. 
Atoms of different elements have different numbers of protons in their nuclei. This number is the 
atomic number that identifies that element. For example, the nucleus of a carbon atom always 
contains 6 protons, and you say that the atomic number of carbon is 6. The atomic number of 
helium is 2, and the atomic number of copper is 29. 
Subatomic particles are extremely small. Electrons are about three times as large as protons, but 
they are 1840 times lighter. They are easy to move. Neutrons have about the same mass as 
protons. 
The electron carries the basic Unit of electrical charge. For historical reasons, an electron's 
charge is considered to be a negative(-) charge. Because it is free to move, an electron actively 
participates in the transfer of electrical energy. 
The proton carries a positive(+) charge, opposite to that of an electron. It has the same size of 
charge as the electron's negative one. Protons are not directly active in the flow of electrical 
energy, but they do influence the flow of electrons. 
The nucleus of an atom has an overall positive electrical charge due to the protons. The 
negatively charged electrons revolve around the positive nucleus. See Figure 2-2. 
Figure 2-2 
Negative electrons revolve in orbits around the positively charged nucleus 
28 
March 2022
Atoms and ions 
Under normal circumstances, the atom has equal numbers of protons and electrons. These 
charges cancel each other out, and the atom as a whole is electrically neutral. 
An atom can receive a negative charge through the addition of electrons. It can receive a positive 
charge through removal of electrons. When charging an atom occurs these ways, the atom 
becomes ionized and is now an ion. For example, a positive ion is an atom that has had one or 
more electrons removed. 
Since protons are firmly bound into the nucleus, only electrons can take part in ionizing the atom. 
Cond11ctors and insulators 
Some materials, including copper and aluminum, have electrons that are easy to free. They are 
said to have many free electrons and are conductors. Conductors allow easy transfer of electrical 
energy. 
Some other materials, such as glass and rubber, have electrons that are very difficult to free. 
They are said to have few free electrons and are insulators. Insulators block the transfer of 
electrical energy. 
Electrostatic charges and fields 
Electrostatic charges and fields are also known as static electricity. Static electricity is energy in 
the form of a stationary electric charge such as th_at stored in thunderclouds or produced by 
friction. For example, when you rub together certain pairs of materials (such as fur and a rubber 
rod), an electrostatic charge is produced. The friction produces heat energy that releases 
electrons from the atoms on the surface of one of the materials. 
Electrical charges 
An object may possess a positive electrical charge, a negative electrical charge, or it may be 
electrically neutral. The type of charge that an object has depends on the number of electrons 
and protons it has. 
If it has ... 
Then it... 
Fewer electrons than protons 
Has a positive charge 
More electrons than protons 
Has a negative charge 
The same number of electrons and protons 
Is neutral 
Law of electrical charges 
A fundamental law governs the way charged particles behave: 
Like charges repel and unlike charges attract. 
March 2022 
29
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
Introduction to electricity 
Negatively charged particles repel other negatively charged particles. They tend to move away 
from each other. Similarly, positively charged particles repel each other. However, negatively 
charged particles attract positively charged particles. They tend to move toward each other. 
Because of this law: 
• Protons ( +) and electrons (-) attract each other. 
• Protons repel other protons. 
• Electrons repel other electrons. 
Electrostatic forces and fields 
The electrical charges on protons and electrons are electrostatic charges. An electrostatic charge 
has an electrostatic field associated with it and, within this field, electrostatic forces occur. These 
forces are the forces of attraction and repulsion between charged particles. 
Electrical diagrams show the lines of force around a negative charge as straight lines with arrows 
pointing toward the charge. See Figure 2-3a. 
Figure 2-3 
Lines of force around negative and positive charges 
-,,\t~ 
...... -•·\/ 
'---.ct-
(a) Lines of force around a negative charge 
/1+V' 
(b) Lines of force around a positive charge 
Diagrams show the lines of force around a positive charge as radiating outward from the charge. 
See Figure 2-3b. 
Figure 2-4 shows how the lines of force around positively and negatively charged objects cause 
forces of attraction and repulsion. 
The strength of the forces of attraction and repulsion depends on: 
• the amount of charge on each object; and 
• the square of the distance between the objects. 
The greater the electric charges on the objects, the greater the electrostatic force. 
Also, the closer the charged objects are to each other, the greater the electrostatic force. 
30 
March 2022

Lines of force in electrostatic fields of charged particles, showing the law of 
electrical charges 
Positive charges repel each other 
Negative charges repel each other 
Positive and negative charges attract each other 
Production and use of electricity 
During removal of electrons from their atoms (so that they are free to move), the moving 
electrons may transfer electrical energy. The term electric current usually refers to this.

The following are examples of ways to apply enough force to remove the electrons: 
• heat-thermo

electrical circuit 
Overview 
Purpose 
The gas technician/fitter requires a basic knowledge of the components and operation of simple 
electrical circuits in order to connect and troubleshoot the type of electrical equipment he/she 
encounters in the gas industry. 
Objectives 
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to: 
• describe the components of a simple electrical circuit; and 
• describe the operation of a simple electrical circuit.

Components of a simple electrical circuit 
circuits 
An electric circuit performs work using electrical energy. The part of the circuit that does the work 
is the load. The circuit provides a path for the flow of electric current. In a closed circuit, the path 
is complete and current can flow. In an open circuit, the path is incomplete and current cannot 
flow. Opening a circuit is possible through breakage, by disconnection from an energy source, or 
by a switch. 
A simple electrical circuit consists of the following components: 
• an energy source (such as a battery or a wall plug); 
• conductors (connecting wires); and 
• a load (a device that uses electrical energy to do work). 
A circuit often has a switch and an overcurrent protective device such as a fuse or circuit breaker. 
Figure 3-1 shows a simple circuit.

Introduction to electricity 
Energy sources, potential, and electromotive force 
An electrical energy source may supply electrical energy in several ways. For example, a wet-cell 
battery produces electrochemical energy, which is in the form of a potential difference between 
the charges on the output terminals. This is the measure of the ability (potential) of a Unit of 
electric charge to do a certain amount of work. You may compare the negative charge at one 
terminal and the positive charge at the other with the low and high-pressure points in a fluid 
piping system. 
The difference in the potential between the two terminals provides the force to drive the current. 
This force is the electromotive force (emf). The Unit that indicates the strength of the emf is the 
volt (V). For example, a power source might be a 12-volt battery. You often call sources of emf 
voltage sources. 
The sizes of voltages may vary a great deal, so the size of the Units used can also vary: 
Voltage

Current flow 
Electric current flows_whenever there is a difference of potential across a circuit. Electrons tend to 
flow toward the positive terminal. The amount of voltage across the circuit determines how much 
current can flow through the load. The polarity of the source determines the direction of current 
flow. 
Ampere (A) is a measure of current, which may be quite small or very large: 
Current

Conductors 
The ease with which a current flows through a conductor varies. In de circuits, the opposition that 
a material offers to the flow of current is what you call resistance. 
A conductor in a circuit should have low resistance, allowing maximum current flow. Copper wire 
is the most commonly used conductor. You may use more expensive (even silver) wires in some 
specialized equipment. 
Materials with high resistance oppose the flow of current. The Unit of measurement of resistance 
is the ohm (0). Some resistances are very large, so you may use a larger Unit:

Load 
The load uses electrical energy to do useful work such as producing motion, light, or sound or 
providing heating. 
The load usually has resistance in the electrical circuit. The energy source performs work by 
driving the current through the resistive load. The term load also refers to the amount of energy 
demanded from the source. For example, when you increase or decrease the load, it means that 
the energy source is supplying more or less energy. 
S"vitches 
A switch opens or closes an electric circuit as required. The simplest type has two pieces of 
conducting metal connected to the conductor of the circuit. You arrange switches so that they can 
easily make or break contact with the conductor. See Figure 3-2. 
Figure 3-2 
Switch opens and closes circuit

Contacts in an electrical relay function as switches in control circuits. These contacts are either 
normally closed (NC) or normally open (NO). When you energize a relay, the contacts switch 
position to energize or de-energize circuits. Control circuits frequently employ relays containing 
both NO and NC contacts depending on the circuit requirements. 
42

GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
Introduction to electricity 
Circuit protective devices 
Circuit protective devices include: 
• fuses; 
• circuit breakers; and 
• thermal and magnetic overloads. 
Operation of a simple electrical circuit 
Electron flow in a circuit 
An electric current is the movement of electrons along a conductor. Electrons are extremely small 
atomic particles that have a negative electric charge. The flow of these electrons through a 
conductor can cause any combination of the following three effects: 
• heating of the conductor; 
• chemical changes; and 
• production of a magnetic field around the conductor. 
You can use these effects to power machinery and other devices. 
An electric circuit is like the flow of water through a piping system. In a piping system, you can 
measure the pressure of the water and the volume of water flowing through the system at any 
point. For water to flow through the pipe, there must be a difference in pressure. The water flows 
from the area of higher pressure to the area of lower pressure. If you measure the pressure at 
several points in the piping system, it will be lower at each point as measured in the direction of 
flow. You usually measure pressure of a liquid in pounds per square inch (psi) in the imperial 
system or in kilopascals (kPa) in the metric system of measurement. 
The amount of water flowing through a piping system depends on two things: 
• the pressure applied across the piping; and 
• the restrictions in the piping. 
The greater the pressure applied to the system, the greater the water flow that will occur at a 
given resistance. 
The restrictions in the piping system include length and diameter of pipe, as well as the number 
of fittings. For example, consider two piping systems: one using small-diameter pipe, the other 
using large-diameter pipe. If you apply the same pressure difference across both piping systems, 
more water will flow through the system with the larger-diameter pipe. Maintaining this pressure 
difference will require a larger pump. You often measure water flow in gallons per minute (gal/ 
min) in the imperial system or in litres per second (Us) in the metric system of measurement. 
Voltage, resistance, and current in a circuit 
The same variables as water flow affect the flow of electricity. The amount of electricity flowing 
through an electric circuit depends on the electrical pressure (termed potential difference or 
voltage) applied and the restriction (termed resistance) in the wiring circuit. 
March 2022 
43
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
Introduction to electricity 
In an electric circuit, the Units of measurement of voltage and electric current are volts (V) and 
amperes (A), respectively. Meanwhile, the ohm is a measure of the restriction in electric circuits, 
which is a function of the cross-sectional area of the conductor and the type of material the 
conductor is made of. 
In Figure 3-3, the top circuit shows a piping system. You use a pump to pump water through the 
piping and back to the tank. The piping system has a valve that you can open and close to control 
the amount of water flowing through the system. The pump develops the pressure that causes 
the water to flow. This pressure is greater at the discharge of the pump and drops throughout the 
system. It is lowest where the water returns to the tank. A differential pressure gauge connected 
between these two points can measure the difference in pressure. 
If the pump is running and the valve is fully open, there is very little restriction to the flow of water 
through the pi

Principles of basic magnetism 
Magnetic materials 
Magnetism is the property certain materials have that allows them to attract other magnetic 
materials. These are called ferromagnetic materials. Iron, nickel, and cobalt are the only naturally 
occurring ferromagnetic metals. (Steel is ferromagnetic but is made from iron.) 
When a magnet strokes ferromagnetic materials across their surface, they also become 
magnets. Magnets that retain their magnetic effects are permanent magnets. Those that do not 
retain their magnetic effects are temporary magnets. 
Electrons, rr1olccules, and magnetism 
Any conductor of electric current acts like a magnet. In fact, it is spinning electrons that cause 
magnetic forces. In most atoms, electrons tend to pair off in orbits that have spins in opposite 
directions. Each spin produces a tiny magnetic field and the magnetic fields of these pairs cancel 
each other. In a magnetic material, however, electrons with similar spins can pair off. Their 
magnetic fields add together and the molecules of the material have a net magnetic field. See 
Figure 4-1. 
66 
March 2022
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
Introduction to electricity 
Figure 4-1 
Molecular alignment in a magnet 
Nonmagnetic 
Electron pair spinning 
in opposite directions 
Non magnetized 
Magnetic 
Electron pair spinning 
in same direction 
Magnetized 
When a ferrom.agnetic material is not magnetized, its molecules are randomly oriented. Their 
magnetic effects work in different directions and cancel each other. In a magnetized metal, the 
molecules are aligned with each other so that the magnetic effects of the molecules all work 
together. This produces a strong magnet. On the other hand, if a magnetic material is partially 
magnetized, only some of the molecules are aligned. This produces a weak magnet. 
If the molecules of a magnet become misaligned again, the material loses its magnetism. This 
can gradually happen. It can also happen if the magnet becomes very hot or receives a strong 
physical shock. 
Magnetic polarity 
The magnetic field is strongest at each end of a magnet. These ends are what you call the poles 
of the magnet. 
The Earth itself acts like a giant magnet and has a magnetic north pole and south pole. When you 
suspend a magnet (see Figure 4-2) so that it is free to move, it will turn so that one pole always 
points toward the Earth's North Pole. In the past, this was the north-seeking pole of the magnet 
and diagrams show this with an N. The other pole was the south-seeking pole and this comes 
with an S in diagrams. 
March 2022

GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 5 
fl
